metadata.title: LANCZOSNET: MULTI-SCALE DEEP GRAPH CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS
metadata.author: Renjie Liao, Zhizhen Zhao, Raquel Urtasun, Richard S. Zemel, University of Toronto, Uber ATG Toronto, Vector Institute, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Canadian Institute for Advanced Research, {rjliao, urtasun, zemel}@cs.toronto.edu, zhizhenz@illinois.edu
metadata.abstract: We propose the Lanczos network (LanczosNet), which uses the Lanczos algorithm to construct low rank approximations of the graph Laplacian for graph convolution. Relying on the tridiagonal decomposition of the Lanczos algorithm, we not only efficiently exploit multi-scale information via fast approximated computation of matrix power but also design learnable spectral filters. Being fully differentiable, LanczosNet facilitates both graph kernel learning as well as learning node embeddings. We show the connection between our LanczosNet and graph based manifold learning methods, especially the diffusion maps. We benchmark our model against several recent deep graph networks on citation networks and QM8 quantum chemistry dataset. Experimental results show that our model achieves the state-of-the-art performance in most tasks.

highlights: Graph-structured data is ubiquitous in real world applications, social networks, gene expression regulatory networks, protein-protein interactions, and many other physical systems

In scenarios where one wants to learn the graph kernel and/or node embeddings, we propose another variant, i.e., adaptive Lanczos network (AdaLanczosNet), which back-propagates through the Lanczos algorithm
Lanczos Step: We investigate the Lanczos step since it will have an impact on the accuracy of the low rank approximation induced by the Lanczos algorithm
We propose LanczosNet which leverages the Lanczos algorithm to construct a low rank approximation of the graph Laplacian
We show that our model has a close relationship with graph based manifold learning, especially diffusion map
Experimental results demonstrate that our model outperforms a range of other graph networks, on challenging graph problems
key_statements: Graph-structured data is ubiquitous in real world applications, social networks, gene expression regulatory networks, protein-protein interactions, and many other physical systems

For supervised and semi-supervised tasks such as graph or node classification and regression, learning based models can be roughly categorized into two classes, formulated either in terms of graph convolutions [2] or recurrent neural networks [3]
Based on the tridiagonal decomposition implied by the Lanczos algorithm, our model exploits the low rank approximation of the graph Laplacian

In scenarios where one wants to learn the graph kernel and/or node embeddings, we propose another variant, i.e., adaptive Lanczos network (AdaLanczosNet), which back-propagates through the Lanczos algorithm

We show that our proposed model is closely related to graph based manifold learning approaches such as diffusion maps which could potentially inspire more work from the intersection between deep graph networks and manifold learning
We present our first model, called Lanczos network (LanczosNet), in which we execute the Lanczos algorithm once per graph and fix the basis throughout inference and learning
We introduce the adaptive Lanczos network (AdaLanczosNet) in which we learn the graph kernel and/or node embedding by back-propagating through the Lanczos algorithm

The Lanczos algorithm is run beforehand once per graph to construct the network and will not be invoked during inference and learning. We explain another variant which back-propagates through the Lanczos algorithm

Graph based Manifold Learning The non-linear dimensionality reduction methods, such as locally linear embedding (LLE) [47], ISOMAP [48], Hessian locally linear embedding [49], Laplacian eigenmaps [50], and diffusion maps [17], assume that the high-dimensional data lie on or close to a low dimensional manifold and use the local affinities in the weighted graph to learn the global features of the data
Lanczos Step: We investigate the Lanczos step since it will have an impact on the accuracy of the low rank approximation induced by the Lanczos algorithm
We propose LanczosNet which leverages the Lanczos algorithm to construct a low rank approximation of the graph Laplacian
We show that our model has a close relationship with graph based manifold learning, especially diffusion map
Experimental results demonstrate that our model outperforms a range of other graph networks, on challenging graph problems
summary: Graph-structured data is ubiquitous in real world applications, social networks, gene expression regulatory networks, protein-protein interactions, and many other physical systems.
Based on the tridiagonal decomposition implied by the Lanczos algorithm, our model exploits the low rank approximation of the graph Laplacian.
We introduce the adaptive Lanczos network (AdaLanczosNet) in which we learn the graph kernel and/or node embedding by back-propagating through the Lanczos algorithm.
Spectral Filter Ideally, we would like to compute Lanczos vectors only once during the inference of a deep graph convolutional network.

With the above parameterization of the graph Laplacian and tridiagonal decomposition, we can back-propagate the loss through the Lanczos algorithm to either the graph kernel parameters θ or the node embedding X.

Connection to Graph Convolution Apart from using diffusion maps to embed node features X at different time scales, one can use it to compute the frequency representations of X as below, X = ΛtU X, (10)

Recall that in the convolution layer Eq (5) of LanczosNet, we use multiple such frequency representations with different scales t and replace the eigenvalues Λ in Eq (10) with their approximation, i.e., Ritz values.
In LanczosNet, spectral filters are applied to the frequency representations which are obtained by projecting the node features X onto multiple diffusion maps with different scales.

They only consider the localized polynomial filter case in our LanczosNet variant and do not explore the low rank decomposition, learnable spectral filter and graph kernel/node embedding learning as we do.

Graph based Manifold Learning The non-linear dimensionality reduction methods, such as locally linear embedding (LLE) [47], ISOMAP [48], Hessian LLE [49], Laplacian eigenmaps [50], and diffusion maps [17], assume that the high-dimensional data lie on or close to a low dimensional manifold and use the local affinities in the weighted graph to learn the global features of the data.

As shown in the 3-rd and 4th rows of the table, learning node embeddings significantly improves the performance for both LanczosNet and AdaLanczosNet and is more effective than learning graph kernels.
We propose LanczosNet which leverages the Lanczos algorithm to construct a low rank approximation of the graph Laplacian.
It not only provides an efficient way to gather multi-scale information for graph convolution but enables learning spectral filters.

We are currently exploring customized eigen-decomposition methods for tridiagonal matrices, which will potentially further improve our AdaLanczosNet. Overall, work in this direction holds promise for allowing deep learning to scale up to very large graph problems.
Work in this direction holds promise for allowing deep learning to scale up to very large graph problems
headline: We propose the Lanczos network, which uses the Lanczos algorithm to construct low rank approximations of the graph Laplacian for graph convolution
